title: 1's and 0's in Binary system
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Which of the following decimal numbers has more  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 0â€™s "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  than "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 1's"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in its "},{"type":"text","text":"binary","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":" representation?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 55 _ { ( 10 ) } = 110111 _ { ( 2 ) } "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 99 _ { ( 10 ) } = 1100011 _ { ( 2 ) } "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 77 _ { ( 10 ) } = 1001101 _ { ( 2 ) } "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 66 _ { ( 10 ) } = 1000010 _ { ( 2 ) } "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 37 _ { ( 10 ) } = 100101 _ { ( 2 ) } "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 55 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" has "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 5 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" 1's, and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" 0's, so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 55 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is not the answer."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 99 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" has "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 4 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" 1's, and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 3 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" 0's, so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 99 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is also not the answer."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 77 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" has "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 4 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" 1's, and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 3 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" 0's, so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 77 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is not the answer, either."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 66 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" has "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 2 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" 1's, and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 5 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" 0's, so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 66 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the answer."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 37 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" has "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 3 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" 1's, and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 3 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" 0's, so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 37 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is not the answer, too."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

replies.body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Pi Han Goh â€“ "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" It's a multiple choice problem. If one of the answers is right, the others are wrong or don't matter, unless it's one of those "All of the Above" or "Both II and IV" answers. The system only allows for the selection of one answer. If the answer is true and is not included in any other answer, then it is sufficient to say that that answer is the correct one, or the problem is too easy because it raises the probability of guessing the correct answer. 66 happened to be the first choice for me, so I tried it first. If it didn't meet the conditions, I would have checked the others."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So in short, because it would break the problem. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Zach Bian â€“ "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" But how do you know that the other numbers don't satisfy the conditions imposed by the problem? "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Pi Han Goh â€“ "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" No, I tested the first option, which met he conditions imposed by the problem. I stopped checking after that. https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Short-circuit_evaluation "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            So you just chose one of the options without testing the rest?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            It doesn't matter. It's the first on the list. The problem says there's only one.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

title: 1's counting sequence
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1, 1, 2, 1, 2, 2, 3, 1, 2, 2, 3, 2, 3, 3, 4, 1, 2, 2, 3, 2, 3, 3, 4, 2, 3, 3, 4, 3, 4, 4, 5, 1, ..."}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This is the beginning of the sequence that counts the number of 1's in the binary representation of the positive integers."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f(x)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be the proportion of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"'s in the first "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" terms of the sequence: for example, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f(20)=\frac{9}{20}."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Find "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle \lim_{x\to\infty} f(x)."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Although the number of 2's is large initially, they eventually get swamped by larger numbers.  This is due to the way the sequence grows."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Consider the first seven terms: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1,1,2,1,2,2,3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  The next term, the eighth is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" but then the next seven terms are just one more than each of the first seven: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2,2,3,2,3,3,4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  The sixteenth term is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" then the process repeats.  Those "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"'s are going to become rare.  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The number of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"'s is increasing polynomially as the number of digits increases exponentially, therefore the eventual proportion will tend to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In fact, every number will tend to zero, not just 2."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Consider the first "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2^{n}-1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" numbers in the sequence, where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a positive real number. How many "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"'s would you expect to find in the sequence? If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a positive integer, the answer would be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{n\choose 2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Why? Because between "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2^{n}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" would be every single possible combination of strings of length "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", filled with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"'s and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"'s (except for all "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"'s). The number of combinations that exactly two of the digits would be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{n\choose 2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{n\choose 2}=\frac{n!}{(n-2)!2!}=\frac{n(n-1)}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which is but a polynomial. The denominator is an exponential function "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2^{n}-1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Therefore, the limit "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n\to\infty"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" would be simply "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Of course, you may argue that this only works for integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". However, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{n(n-1)}{2(2^{n}+1)}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a function close enough to the original "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f(n)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" that you can reasonably expect that both functions behave the same when "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n\to\infty"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: Counting Sheep

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If we denote David by A, Harry by B, Sam by C and Peter by D we can find the answer in the following way. Since A + B + C = D and A + B + C + D = 44, it is easy to see that D has 22 sheep. So A + B + C = 22. We can use this along with the two other facts, A + 3 = B - 1 and C - 3 = 3A, to find that A has 3, B has 7, C has 12 and D has 22. In a little more detail:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A + B + C = 22 (1)
A + 3 = B - 1 (2)
C - 3 = 3A (3)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Rearrange (3) to give C = 3A + 3 and replace the C in (1) to give A + B + 3A + 3 = 22. Simplified this gives B = 19 - 4A (4). Rearrange (2) to give B - A = 4. Use (4) in the place of B to give 19 - 4A - A = 4 to give A = 3. Now use A to work out B, and then C."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned}
\text {Let David have "w" sheep.}\\
\text {Let Harry have "x" sheep.}\\
\text {Let Sam have "y" sheep.}\\
\text {Let Peter have "z" sheep.}\\ \\
\text{From first condition}:-\\
w + 3 & = x - 1\\
w & = x - 4 \longrightarrow \boxed{1}\\ \\
y & = w + x + z\\
w & = y - x - z \longrightarrow \boxed{2}\\ \\
z - 3 & = 3w\\
3w & = z - 3 \longrightarrow \boxed{3}\\ \\
w + x + y + z & = 4 Ã— 11 = 44 \longrightarrow \boxed{4}\\ \\ \\
\text{Adding 1 and 2, we get}:-\\
2w & = y - z - 4\\
z & = y - 4 - 2w \longrightarrow \boxed{5}\\ \\
\text{Adding 5 and 3, we get}:-\\
5w & = y - 7 \longrightarrow \boxed{6}\\ \\ \\
\text{ From 1}:-\\
x & = w + 4\\ \\
\text{From 5}:-\\
z & = y - 4 - 2w\\ \\ \\
\text{Substituting the above two equations in 4, we get}:-\\
w + w + 4 + y + y - 4 - 2w & = 44\\
2y & = 44\\
y & = 22\\ \\ \\
\text{Substituting y = 22 in 6, we get}:-\\
5w & = 22 - 7\\
5w & = 15\\
w & = \boxed {3}\\ \\
\text{So, David has 3 sheep} \end{aligned}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}
